content.description: One of the best and most intimidating problems in little cottonwood.  Begin sitting with your right hand on a large right facing sidepull and left hand on a smaller left facing sidepull.  Climb up and left.  Finish with a desperate, terrifying mantel.
Stay right of the arete on slopey hands and dime-edged feet to attain the upper slab. Great technical problem.
content.location: This problem is located on the south/stream side of the Shivers Boulder, just left of a partially decaying cottonwood tree. (See tree photo.)

content.description:
This thing is a monster of a problem. Climb the very slopey arete using some of that LCC slab tech. The crux comes right after getting over "the drip" when trying to get a high foot. The rock is perfect, probably best climbing in the cooler months of fall/winter.

VERY FUN PROBLEM
content.protection: a few pads, a fall from the top will easily make you bottom out if you only have one pad under you. Attentive spotter too, although the falls are pretty straight forward.
content.location:
Located at the south-western corner of the boulder next to all the slab problems. Start matched on the huge "drip" about 5 feet up and climb the arete.

Downclimb the tree with all the bark stripped off.

content.description: A forgotten problem and a fun one to piece together. Start on the right side of the Riverside Arete (left hand on the arete) and traverse right through the sloper scoop, finishing on Boone's Problem. Very temp dependent.
content.location: A rightward traverse of the west face.

content.description:
Less of a slab than the name suggests, but does rely on a few committing friction moves.

Start on the two crimps just right of the moss and work up discovering that all those wonderful looking features from the bottom are sagging slopers.  One or two friction moves and top out.

This is listed as V3, but those crimps feel like jugs after climbing its V4 neighbor.
content.protection: Due to the location of the tree a pad is difficult to get under you.  Probably best not to fall.

content.description:
A right-to-left traverse of the slabby side of the boulder. Start on the right side of Riverside Arete, turn the corner, and traverse left, staying low. Higher is easier and also fun. Finish on Downclimb Corner.

Perfect footwork trainer, especially with how slippery it is.
content.location: Start on Riverside Arete Right and traverse left to Downclimb Corner.

content.description: Start same as Jim but go straight to 12 o'clock instead of heading out left.
Starts on two separate side pulls and moves up and to the left
content.location: Its on the east side of the boulder, first thing visible on the way from Papa Bells boulder

content.description: Thin moves with a little throw for the top
content.location: Located between Feck and the Riverside arete (off route), thin climbing to the top.  Probably done before and just a little harder than Feck.  Very good.

content.description:
Amazing slabbing on the Shivers boulder and one of the best v4s in the canyon.

Start in the middle of the shivers boulder opposite the river. Fresh rubber is a plus!
content.location: obvious tall slab to the left of the riverside arete.  Stay right of the mossy patch

content.description: Start in the sloper scoop with a decent left hand sidepull and nice right hand sloper. Hit the upside down right hand pinch and press into the scoop. Funky.
content.location: Center of the sloper scoop on the west face.

content.description: From BB: Start the same as for Shivers but head straight up the arete.
Start as for Shivers, but move right on the face and finish up Jim.
Start on the right side of the sloper scoop, fire up to a nice right hand pinch and mantle into the scoop. Highstep onto the slab and top out.
content.location: West side of the boulder, starting on the right side of the obvious sloper scoop.
